Info Slide: Monetary financing, or the monetization of government deficits, is a monetary policy whereby a central bank purchases debt directly from that country's government in order to finance a government deficit. This has two effects: it (1) facilitates government spending, and (2) increases the supply of money in an economy. Monetizing government deficits differs from quantitative easing in the sense that the former involves purchasing bonds directly from the government, whereas the latter involves buying bonds and other financial assets on the secondary (i.e. open) market. The European Central Bank is different from many central banks because it performs the typical functions of a central bank across all countries which use the Euro.
Motion: THBT the European Central Bank should monetize the government deficits of Eurozone countries experiencing financial crises. (Monetary financing)
